ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live or recorded lecture (optional but encouraged attendance) and live sections
Lectures were primarily live virtual. We also had one virtual discussion section per week.
Virtual discussion section
discussion section
live virtual lecture and live virtual sections
Live lectures were recorded, which were available for viewing afterwards.
Live discussion section to accompany the lecture, which could be watched asynchronously as well
discussion section
virtual discussion section
live and recorded lecture
There was a synchronous discussion section in addition to the virtual lectures.
I also went to live lecture sometimes
n/a
Live/recorded lectures + weekly discussion section
also had discussion section
Lectures were live and posted on Canvas after class. The course also involved live discussion sections.
Section was a seminar style class.
I combined watching lecture live and recordings.
When there were technical difficulties during normal lecture time, lectures were recorded and posted on Canvas the same day.
Live virtual discussion section/seminar weekly
Discussion section
Virtual Tours of Historical Facilities and Library Tours
Live virtual lecture and virtual seminar.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned more about the history of the medical profession, and different ideas/methods/concepts of disease and health over time.

I learned about different Western medical cultures, starting from Hippocrates and ending today. We tracked themes such as disease epistemologies, what it means to be a "good" doctor, and medical education. The course also raises important questions about what medicine could and should be, and encourages students to think about them.

I learned about an overview of the history of Western medicine from Hippocrates until the late 1900s. I also developed skills on writing historical papers. I learned a lot about how different approaches to medicine evolved as well as many of the social factors that influenced these changes.
how to analyze and connect historical concepts, recurring themes throughout western medicine

A greater understanding of the cultural aspects of society that shaped modern western medicine. We reviewed events in history from antiquity to the present day and although it was daunting to cover so much of history, Professor Warner made it very enjoyable with engaging lectures.

I learned a LOT about the history of Western medicine, starting from Hippocrates to today. This course covered Greek/Roman/Arabic/Middle Eastern medieval medicine, the Parisian medicine reformation, epidemics, prejudices against gender and race, etc. A main focus of the class was how did the study AND the administration of medicine change over time.

I understood the medical and sociological foundations to the growth and various intersecting movements of medicine in Europe and the U.S (from Ancient Greece to "modernity" but really the 1990s with the AIDS epidemic). I learned how to explore online library archives and databases offered through Yale and from other institutions like the Library of Congress through the research paper assignment.
a broad foundational knowledge of western medicine. learned about frameworks within it is useful to think about medicine in the US.
I learned a lot about medicine throughout history and the cultural forces shaping medicine today!
Changes and continuities of western medicine over time

I gained extensive knowledge about the historical narrative of western medicine and the ways in which it continues to plague the medical system today. Very important perspective and knowledge to have as I enter medical school and eventually clinical medicine!
I learned the history of medicine from 0 AD to today. It was fascinating to learn the progression of the medical field.

I developed insights on how medical knowledge was obtained over thousands of years, how the medical profession (and perceptions of it) changed over time, who and who didn't compose the medical profession over the years.

Understanding of the trajectory of humanizing medicine in western cultures; how this has changed and developed over time and in different places; the ways in which belief systems and structural systems importantly impact medicine and its delivery
History of Western medicine, from Hippocrates until now.

I learned about the many facets of western medicine since the Ancient Greek period. Topics covered included the modernization of hospitals, the empiricism rationalism debate in medicine, medical examination subjects, and the exclusion of individuals in the medical marketplace.
I learned about the history of medicine focusing on western medicine. I learned how to do primary source analysis.
I learned about the history of medicine in the western world, including prominent physicians, theories, and movements.
I learned about the history of western medicine and many important figures in medical history, medical advancements, and explanations for different attitudes and kinds of medical thinking.

Comprehensive introduction to the history of medical epistemology, practice, education and the institutions of Western Europe and the United States. The latter half of the course primarily focuses on the history of U.S. public health and medicine.
Survey of major developments in Western Medicine from Ancient times until the present.
Learned an immense amount about the social, philosophical, and scientific developments of western medicine and the conflicts and problems that motivated these.

I learned a great deal about the ways that medicine and medical professionals interact with various aspects of society, culture, politics, and religion. Before taking this course, I really had no idea that medicine had such a great impact and was so impacted by such seemingly unrelated aspects of life in Western civilization.
I learned a lot about the evolution of Western medicine throughout history. This course was really engaging and taught us a lot about where many of the features of modern medicine originated.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: engaging section, interesting lectures (most of the time), and good assessment structure: 24hr midterm, paper, 24hr final (grades well distributed) 
 
Weakness: Might be good to mandate attendance at one lecture a week to increase engagement. It was easy to get behind by not watching the lectures on schedule.

At the end of the course, you end up with a really clear picture of how we've ended up in this current medical moment. The lectures are engaging and the curriculum is well thought out. I do wish that there were more secondary source readings, the primary sources were great but I didn't really know what to do with them sometimes.

The strength of the course is in Professor Warner and the teaching team. I learned so much throughout the course, which I am sure I will use later on in my life. Anyone could learn the material and really enjoy it. There was emphasis on large themes and analysis on specific events. The suggestion provided to create a timeline significantly helped. I can't think of any weaknesses.
this was a great class all around! i learned a lot!

I cannot say it more--this class is AMAZING. From the content involved, to the way Professor Warner presented material, to the interesting readings that made me WANT to read, this class is everything a humanities class should be. The one thing that could be improved could be having conference sessions with the TFs for a first draft of the final paper, since we were just asked to do a proposal and then follow a rubric.

The course is a survey course that covers thousands of years in modernity, but Professor Warner is a gem at highlighting the movements in a way that is not confusing, goes into some depth, but also stays on pace.

The course started off with reasonable amounts of reading but it became a bit ridiculous around Week 7, when the reading load per week ended up being triple what it had been in any week from Week 1 through Week 6. Also, there should have been more transparency as to how the midterm (and final) exam would be graded, since stylistics were not something that I and a few other students thought would be considered, but we ended up getting docked off for this on the midterm. In addition, while it is useful to dive into texts that don't necessarily relate to the week's topics, it would be helpful if the primary literature assigned for the week actually aligned from the same time period or perhaps even themes as discussed in the lectures.

strength - super interesting content, learned a lot, sharpened up my writing skills

weaknesses - I think some of the readings became a little redundant which made it a bit monotonous. I also would like more section options if possible/earlier on during the day.
The strengths of this course were the lectures! A weakness was the amount of reading; it was usually too much for me to get done in a week but also too much for us to discuss in section anyway.
Interesting and nice discussion sections
This was an incredible course -- so engaging, fun, and important!
I have no weaknesses to report from the course. I loved all the lectures. I found the material very engaging and it was all new to me.

While the lecture material was interesting, it was often read out by Professor Warner on a backdrop of painting/photograph slides. There wasn't any notes or text to follow the lecture with, so it was hard to retain information.
Strengths were the professor and the TAs -- they are all very knowledgeable and passionate about the material, which helps student learning. It was very well organized too. No weaknesses

The teaching team--especially Professor Warner--cared so much about supporting students and engaging in a way that was meaningful. Course content was always well curated, thoughtful, and clear. I left each class thinking about something new.

Strengths: Really interesting material, engaging lecture style, great job at condensing the many facts and figures of Western medicine into one semester while still focusing us in on the most important themes 

Weakness: Grades and discussion section experience felt very TA-dependent

Professor Warner is an excellent lecturer, even during a period of virtual learning. The course's lectures were very easy to follow, and the incorporation of primary sources and images were a wise addition to the lectures. Another strength of the course was its use of video clips and news broadcasts from different time periods to reinforce the material being taught.
Professor Warner is amazing!! He is the strength of this course!

The strength was definitely my TF, Megann, who worked very hard to make discussion sections engaging and informative and provided great feedback to help me improve my writing in the course. I also enjoyed the lectures and thought Prof. Warner was very engaging.
I loved this course!! Professor Warner is so amazing and interesting and the topics were always engaging and insightful.
Not exactly a weakness, but each lecture covers a lot of material, so you have to really keep up with your note-taking during class!
Strengths: Lectures were interesting and engaging and discussion sections were extremely pleasant. No weaknesses
The course was pretty interesting and the material was easy to grasp. I think possible having review sessions or going over the timeline and central concepts explicitly would have been helpful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
open note 24hr exams were helpful (unsure if this is typical or an adjustment)
In section the whiteboard function was used and sometimes we would collab on a google doc - that facilitated online learning well
Time allotted for exams was helpful.

This course really took advantage of the virtual format to keep us engaged. I appreciated the special courses, especially when Barbara gave the tour of the dissection theater in Bologna, Italy. I still learned a lot through the lectures and discussion sections even though they were virtual.

Professor Warner tried really hard to make the most of the virtual setting and I am super appreciative of it. I think that the adapting of the midterm and final exams to be written essays was a great way to bridge the challenges of the semester.

I think this class adapted to the COVID-19 pandemic pretty well, as the lectures and discussion sections happened as it normally would have. In fact, we talked about how COVID-19 is similar to many other historical events, which was interesting to consider!

The professor held live lectures that were also recorded, which I appreciated. But, the professor rarely stopped to ask if there were any questions, and no students wrote anything in the Zoom chat because they had not been addressed in Week 1/2. Thus, there was no room for dialogue with the professor and no time to ask clarifying questions, which could have been a major asset to the course especially given the lack of interpersonal interaction during the pandemic.
I thought Professor Warner did a great job making the class compatible with pandemic virtual reality that we are living in.
Breakout rooms during discussion section were helpful for smaller discussions and in-depth conversations.
Lectures and section were interactive, smooth, and clear.

Because Professor Warner encouraged us to attend lecture if we were able to and asked us (though didn't require us) to keep cameras on, it actually made  lecture feel more "real" and close to the in-person experience.

Every live lecture for this course was posted on Canvas afterwards, which was very helpful when preparing for the midterm and final examinations. All of the readings for the course were posted on Canvas as well, and there was no need to purchase textbooks or other course materials.
Professor Warner and his TAs were incredibly understanding of the pandemic. All professors should model their efforts.
I think the course was geared well towards learning during the pandemic.
They were really good about being accommodating with the 24 hr open notebook exams and section was a great place to synthesize learning and topics and connect to modern times.
Since this was a live virtual lecture, the course went very smoothly despite COVID-19 restrictions!
This course was generally well-adapted to COVID restrictions. Professor Warner's lectures were sometimes delayed by technological difficulties, but on the whole this was not a huge problem.
The format of the class was great for virtual learning and virtual section was helpful as well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, take this course! Very interesting and engaging material, even if you have no interest in medicine. The research paper is very open ended and you can largely choose your own course of study. Exams not difficult, workload not high, readings are usually short and intellectually stimulating. Everything you could want in a class.
yes, great professor, and very interesting course material.
Absolutely. Learning about the history of medicine is important for everyone, and it helps you make sense of the world we live in.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Whether you are someone majoring in the sciences or history, you will learn so much. I came out of many lectures thinking about what the history meant on how medicine is practiced today. The course gives a lot of context of why medicine is the way it is today.
yes! :DD

Yes!! Professor Warner truly care about students and despite the challenges of this semester it was a great class. I think that had it had been a normal semester in person lecture series, this would have been my favorite class of the semester. I especially loved how Professor Warner engaged the material with the social context of each historical era. Also, his during the minutes before class, his pug would make an appearance and honestly 10/10 worth taking the class to see his dog on camera!

If you are new to the field of history of medicine, this is THE class to take. We went through literally the entire history of Western medicine. Although it does only cover Western medicine, it is what is most relevant to us here in the U.S. and I found it to be super helpful in putting medicine in context. Definitely worth it to take if you are a pre-med.

Take this course if you are genuinely interested in medicine and/or public health as a future profession. But, do not take this course if you are looking for an easy A. The workload is light and the TAs seem nice, but unfortunately there isn't very much transparency with respect to exam grading and it seems fairly arbitrary where you land on the A, A-, B+, B scale.
yes I would! great HSHM elective choice, useful and interesting content to contextualize other classes.
Yes! Especially a pre-med student, although I think everyone could benefit from learning more about the cultures of Western Medicine, especially during a pandemic.
Yes the professors and TAs are all great
I would absolutely recommend this course to another person! This was an incredibly enjoyable course.

Yes absolutely! I love Professor Warner. I actually took this class partly because I loved his other course Media and Medicine so much. I would suggest that course because I think its very engaging and the material is fascinating. It is very cool to learn how we arrived at our current medical system.
Yes, I highly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning about the evolution of the medical profession over different years, places, and cultures.

YES!! Such a good course that all students who wish to understand the intersection of medicine, history, and social structures should take. Professor Warner made me look forward to coming to every lecture with his level of knowledge, engagement, thoughtfulness, and guest appearances of his puppy! Workload was also super manageable.
Yes, especially anyone looking to go into medicine. We learned not just historical facts, but also deeper themes and patterns that pushed us to challenge the way things are today.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! I believe this course teaches critical knowledge that every college student should learn about at some point. The course covered American history topics such as the Tuskegee Experiment and the AIDS Epidemic, which provide critical lessons about public health and policy for the future.
Yes! Professor Warner is amazing and you learn very important history.
Yes! It was a very interesting class.
Yes!!! Amazing and I came away with so much knowledge about medicine's history.

If you are interested in the history of medicine and public health and the forces that shaped our modern medical knowledge and institutions, then absolutely! Great class for those interested in public health and pre-med students; gives great perspective on modern medical practices which is very useful for those who want to enter the medical profession.
Yes I would recommend this course, it was very interesting and the teaching staff was very kind and always willing to help.
Would highly recommend this course to those interested in history and health.
Yes! This course has something for everyone. I was amazed by how many aspects of life the material in this class touched on, far beyond the reach of what I thought medicine was before.
Yes, Professor Warner is lovely and the course is pretty interesting.
